description: From Middle English penetratyve, penetratif, from Medieval Latin penetrativus, from (the participle stem of) Latin penetrāre (“to penetrate”).

adjectives.description: penetrative (comparative more penetrative, superlative most penetrative)

entries.meaning: That can or does physically penetrate something; piercing, penetrating. [from 15th c.]
Displaying insight or discrimination; acute; penetrating. [from 17th c.]
(sports) That can penetrate opposition defences. [from 20th c.]
Pertaining to sexual activity involving penetration by the penis. [from 20th c.]
examples: I've been in a relationship for nearly a year and we have an amazing sex life as is, but we've never managed penetrative sex.
